name: Isabella P. AOSE
comment info: This graph depicts the distribution of young people (aged 15-24) now and how that is projected to change in the next 27 years. I notice that by 2050, Africa is projected to have the highest percentage of young people (35%). In human geography, we discussed how many countries of Africa have expansive population pyramids which means their population is young and growing. This is because most of these countries are developing countries which means they have not achieved a significant degree of industrialization relative to their populations, and have, in most cases, a medium to low standard of living. They lack access to education, especially for women, and they lack access to contraceptives/family planning. Therefore, women are getting married very young and having many kids. Additionally, having children in countries like Africa can be helpful because they can work for the family. On the other hand, I noticed that in 2050 Northern America will have the lowest percentage of young people (3.5%). This is most likely because of the cost of having children in the developed countries of North America. Since it costs so much, people are going to stop having as many children because they cannot afford it. Finally, I noticed that Eastern and Southeastern Asia suffered a dramatic decline in young people between the years 2023 and 2050. This is because countries like China and Japan have an aging population. Especially with China's one-child rule, the younger population will shrink. PT.2

name: Joshua Teague
comment info: There is a sizeable increase in population for Africa, a historically underdeveloped continent as its general population lack many essentials like quantitative water resources, long-term housing solutions, and stable economic and social growth. The government in Africa has been corrupt in many, if not all, recognized countries within the continent, making it easy to stay away from them for immigration purposes. The increase in the youth population is more than likely because of the health conditions on each continent. As seen per the graph, Asia overall takes the largest dive in population growth, contributed mainly by the fact that Asia has the worst air quality and a significantly low birth rate. Struggling with pollution and a significant lack of resources, Asia seems to be the only continent steadily declining in its living environment as a desirable living place. With pollution kept in mind, Africa is by far the least industrialized continent in the world. As overpopulation ensues, Africa will make for a great alternative as it makes up ~20% of the world's land mass, meaning there is plenty of space for immigration and development, as it has generally gone unused.

name: Grace
comment info: Africa is expected to experience a 12% increase in population over the next 25 years, while Western Asia is projected to grow by only 0.4%. In contrast, the rest of the world is predicted to have a slight decline in population. This growth presents both advantages and difficulties. On one hand, it fosters greater diversity within the population. Moreover, the stability of other regions indicates societal stability and less need for extensive future planning due to resource loss. However, Africa encounters challenges like overcrowding and a severe lack of resources. The inadequate infrastructure in Africa raises concerns about sustaining the expanding population, potentially leading to starvation and higher mortality rates. Additionally, the population surge may result in a decrease in job availability, with certain sectors becoming oversaturated. This could lead to lower wages and an increase in homelessness. Observing the data, I questioned Africa's ability to manage this substantial population growth. The graph is relevant to the global community as it demonstrates the projected population shifts in the coming years. A fitting title for this graph could be "Population Growth: Is Your Region Ready for the Future?" By selecting an inclusive title, readers can relate the graph to their own area and contemplate the potential consequences of population growth.

name: Jackson Woodward
comment info:
3/27/2024

	This graph reflects the percentage of the world’s youth, that is people between the ages of 15 and 24, which is predicted to belong to each of a number of distinct geographical regions by 2050. The graph suggests that 35% of the world’s youth will reside in Africa, which seems to coincide with that continent’s broader development as many countries there begin to transform into modern societies. It seems important to note that this graph, however, seems misleading. The implication it delivers is that Africa will experience a population boom of sorts and so its youth population will rise dramatically. This may well be true; however, if one considers that Africa is an entire continent comprising more than 20% of the Earth’s total landmass, the context of this number changes. Indeed, while the graph’s constructors have split up Asia into three separate regions, when one combines these numbers, it becomes evident that the Asian continent will contain 47.4% of the world’s youth population in 2050, the lion’s share. This data is, for whatever reason, hidden in the graph. It seems, furthermore, nonsensical to consider what percentage of the world’s youth such massive continents will hold as it renders the data shallow, as well as reinforcing misguided conceptions of these continents as singular places instead of diverse regions. One cannot, therefore, examine much from this data.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Jackson Woodward --

You bring up many interesting points.  I hope you have an opportunity to discuss them with your classmates. 
 
I’m asking you to share with us evidence of these statements you make:

The graph suggests that 35% of the world’s youth will reside in Africa, which seems to coincide with that continent’s broader development as many countries there begin to transform into modern societies.
Does being a “modern society” result in an increase in population?  Take a look at other regions with “modern societies” in the graph.

Africa will experience a population boom of sorts and so its youth population will rise dramatically.  Do we know how the African youth population will rise or just its change in share of the world’s youth population?  What statistics do we need to know to make your claim?

You suggest that the three Asian regions should be combined to be comparable to comparable to Africa.  If this is done, then their share of the youth population decreases from 57% to 47.4% of the global youth population.  How does this compare to Africa?

What story does this graph tell?  Learn more from the New York Times article that included this graph.  Its free link will be revealed on Friday.

To learn more about United Nations findings, search online for the source report (given below the graph).
